goals.question: What is the trend of electricity consumption in Iowa over the years?
goals.visualization: Line chart of electricity consumption over time
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if there is an increase or decrease in electricity consumption in Iowa over the years.

goals.question: What is the distribution of residential electricity consumption in Iowa?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the range of residential electricity consumption in Iowa and if there are any outliers.

goals.question: What is the correlation between commercial and industrial electricity consumption in Iowa?
goals.visualization: Scatter plot of commercial and industrial electricity consumption
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if there is a positive or negative correlation between commercial and industrial electricity consumption in Iowa.

goals.question: What is the average electricity consumption per capita in Iowa?
goals.visualization: Bar chart of electricity consumption per capita
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the average electricity consumption per person in Iowa and how it compares to other states.

goals.question: What is the distribution of electricity rates in Iowa?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the range of electricity rates in Iowa and if there are any outliers or extreme values.

code:
```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Load data
data = pd.read_csv('iowa-electricity.csv')

# Convert date fields to date types
data['Date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['Date'], format='%Y-%m-%d', errors='coerce')

# Drop rows with NaT values
data = data[pd.notna(data['Date'])]

# Set Date as index
data.set_index('Date', inplace=True)

# Create line chart
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))
ax.plot(data.index, data['Consumption (MWH)'], color='blue')

# Set chart title and axis labels
ax.set_title('What is the trend of electricity consumption in Iowa over the years?', wrap=True)
ax.set_xlabel('Year')
ax.set_ylabel('Electricity Consumption (MWH)')

# Rotate x-axis labels for legibility
plt.xticks(rotation=45)

# Show plot
plt.show()
```

```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    sns.set_style('whitegrid')
    plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
    sns.histplot(data=data, x='residential', kde=True, color='blue')
    plt.axvline(data['residential'].mean(), color='red', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=2, label=f'Mean: {data["residential"].mean():.2f}')
    plt.axvline(data['residential'].median(), color='green', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=2, label=f'Median: {data["residential"].median():.2f}')
    plt.xlabel('Residential Electricity Consumption (kWh)')
    plt.ylabel('Frequency')
    plt.title('What is the distribution of residential electricity consumption in Iowa?')
    plt.legend()
    plt.show()
    return plt

chart = plot(data)
```

```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data = data[['Commercial', 'Industrial']]
    plt.scatter(data['Commercial'], data['Industrial'], alpha=0.5)
    plt.xlabel('Commercial Electricity Consumption')
    plt.ylabel('Industrial Electricity Consumption')
    plt.title('What is the correlation between commercial and industrial electricity consumption in Iowa?')
    return plt

data = pd.read_csv('iowa-electricity.csv')
chart = plot(data)
```

```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Importing the dataset
data = pd.read_csv('iowa-electricity.csv')

# Calculating the average electricity consumption per capita in Iowa
iowa_data = data[data['state'] == 'Iowa']
iowa_avg = iowa_data['consumption'].mean()

# Creating a bar chart of electricity consumption per capita
plt.bar(data['state'], data['consumption'])
plt.axhline(y=iowa_avg, color='r', linestyle='-', label=f'Iowa Average: {iowa_avg:.2f}')
plt.legend()
plt.xticks(rotation=90)
plt.title('What is the average electricity consumption per capita in Iowa?', wrap=True)

# Returning the plot
plt.show()
```

```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    sns.set(style="whitegrid")
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))
    sns.boxplot(x=data['Residential'], ax=ax, color='skyblue')
    ax.axvline(data['Residential'].median(), color='red', linestyle='--', label=f'Median: {data["Residential"].median():.2f}')
    ax.axvline(data['Residential'].quantile(0.25), color='green', linestyle='--', label=f'Q1: {data["Residential"].quantile(0.25):.2f}')
    ax.axvline(data['Residential'].quantile(0.75), color='orange', linestyle='--', label=f'Q3: {data["Residential"].quantile(0.75):.2f}')
    ax.set_xlabel('Electricity Rates')
    ax.set_ylabel('Residential')
    ax.set_title('What is the distribution of electricity rates in Iowa?')
    ax.legend()
    plt.show()
    return plt

chart = plot(data)
```
